unnormalised: The Curious Case of the Never-Ending Academic Transcript
normalised: The Curious Case of the Never-Ending Academic Transcript

unnormalised: Ah, the academic transcript. That glorious, often dreaded, chronicle of our intellectual adventures, or, let’s be honest, sometimes just surviving organic chemistry. As an education columnist, I’ve seen my share of these documents, from the pristine, perfectly formatted versions submitted to prestigious universities to the slightly crumpled, coffee-stained copies clutched by anxious job applicants. And let me tell you, they’re a goldmine of unintentional comedy.
normalised: Ah, the academic transcript. That glorious, often dreaded, chronicle of our intellectual adventures, or, let's be honest, sometimes just surviving organic chemistry. As an education columnist, I've seen my share of these documents, from the pristine, perfectly formatted versions submitted to prestigious universities to the slightly crumpled, coffee-stained copies clutched by anxious job applicants. And let me tell you, they're a goldmine of unintentional comedy.

unnormalised: Firstly, there's the sheer volume of titles. From "B.A. (Hons.) in English Lit." to "M.Sc. in Theoretical Physics," we accumulate more acronyms than a NASA engineer. My personal favourite was a transcript I saw from someone who apparently achieved "Cert. IV in Advanced Basket Weaving," awarded in 2008 by "The National School of Really Serious Basketry." (I made that last one up, but you get the point!)
normalised: Firstly, there's the sheer volume of titles. From "B-A (Hons.) in English Lit." to "M-S-C. in Theoretical Physics," we accumulate more acronyms than an N-A-S-A engineer. My personal favourite was a transcript I saw from someone who apparently achieved "Cert. four in Advanced Basket Weaving," awarded in two thousand and eight by "The National School of Really Serious Basketry." (I made that last one up, but you get the point!)

unnormalised: Then, of course, you have the descriptions of the achievements themselves. Remember that time you scraped by with a measly "Pass" in "Underwater Basket Weaving 101"? Well, it's forever etched in your academic history, probably right next to that "A+" you got in "Intro to Existential Dread." And who can forget those "Merit" awards in "Advanced Procrastination Techniques"? Ok, maybe not. The point is that achievements are there for life, or unless the campus burns to the ground.

unnormalised: Speaking of achievements, there are these certificates you get. Like "Certificate of Completion of Online Course in Project Management," whatever that is. These online courses are often completed in less than a week, and it will be listed just below your PhD in Nuclear Engineering, acquired in 2015, from IIT Bombay. One thing to watch out for is how your name is spelt. Is it "Mr. Rakesh Sharma," "Rakesh Kr. Sharma," "R. Sharma" or "Rak Sharma"? These can cause a massive headache, later on, so make sure you get it right.

unnormalised: The problem with the modern academic transcript is how much information is crammed in there. Everything from the GPA to the university's official seal is important, but sometimes there are also odd items that somehow make it in there. In a transcript I saw last week, there was an annotation saying, "attended campus from 2014-2018; please note: student never returned his overdue library book." Which really makes you think - did the university really have to include that?

unnormalised: But the best transcripts are the ones that reflect the true, unvarnished reality of student life. The one with the note from Prof. Gupta explaining that the student's consistent lateness was due to "an unfortunate addiction to online Ludo." Or the one where the Registrar accidentally included the student's food delivery app order history. (Turns out, Priya had a serious weakness for midnight biryani.)

unnormalised: So, next time you're staring at your own academic transcript, feeling a mix of pride and slight embarrassment, remember that it's more than just a list of grades and degrees. It's a window into your past self, a testament to your triumphs and tribulations, and a surprisingly hilarious document when viewed with the right perspective. After all, who needs a stand-up comedian when you have a lifetime of "Intro to Existential Dread" to draw inspiration from?
